stem: A 17-year-old male is brought to the ED reporting severe chest pain and a 'racing heart' after a party. Based on the documentation in the Adolescent Emergency & Substance Screening tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute cardiac distress in an adolescent.
Background: Previously healthy. Participant in track/field.
Assessment: Client is extremely restless, picking at his skin, and has a BP of 188/110.
Recommendation: Immediate toxicology screen and cardiovascular stabilization.

tabs.title: Emergency Substance Screen
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
EKGST-segment depression in Lead II, III, aVFInferior wall ischemia
Pupils8mm (Mydriasis)Sympathetic stimulation
Troponin I0.08 ng/mL (Elevated)Myocardial Injury
Tox ScreenPositive for Cocaine and amphetaminesSympathomimetics

actionOptions.text: Administer IV Benzodiazepines (e.g., Diazepam) as prescribed for sedation
Obtain serial EKGs to monitor for worsening ischemia
Provide high-flow caffeine to help the client stay awake for assessment
Withhold all IV fluids to prevent further blood pressure increases

parameterOptions.text: Blood pressure and heart rate monitoring
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a Cocaine-Induced Myocardial Ischemia (c2) in an adolescent. The drug causes massive coronary artery vasospasm and increases myocardial oxygen demand, leading to ischemia (ST depression) and minor injury (Elevated Troponin). Priority actions for all stimulant-induced cardiac issues are Benzodiazepines (a1) (to bring down the sympathetic storm) and serial EKGs (a2) to track the resolution of the vasospasm. Monitoring Vital Signs (p1) and the EKG (p2) is mandatory for safely managing the hypertensive crisis.
clinicalPearls: In young people without heart disease, cocaine is the #1 cause of MI.
Vasospasm is the mechanism, which is why vasodilators and sedatives are the treatment, NOT beta-blockers (which can worsen the spasm).
Mydriasis (dilated pupils) is a hallmark sign of stimulant use in the ED.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a teen 'can't have a heart attack'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Anyone with chest pain and ST-segment changes on an EKG is having a heart attack. If the tox screen is positive, it's drug-induced, but it is still a life-threatening MI.

mnemonic.title: Stimulant Storm
mnemonic.expansion: S-ST changes. T-Tachycardia. O-Overdose of BP. R-Restless. M-Mydriasis (Big pupils).
